entry.author: By Sam Fleming and Philip Stafford
entry.headline: JPMorgan tells clearers to build bigger buffers
entry.body:
Clearing houses which guarantee the smooth completion of financial transactions ranging from derivatives trades to commodities deals should be required to line up larger financial buffers to prevent triggering a future market disaster, a top investment bank has argued.

JPMorgan Chase is to warn in a forthcoming paper that the current system for dealing with failing clearing houses is brittle and opaque, and requires a new resolution framework to tackle major failures.

entry.author: By Martin Arnold, Banking Editor
entry.headline: Sir Win Bischoff to take chairman role at JPMorgan Securities
entry.body: Charlie Bibby

entry.author: By Henny Sender in New York
entry.headline: Sankaty to buy JPMorgan debt portfolio for $1bn
entry.body:
Sankaty Advisors, the credit arm of Bain Capital, is paying more than $1bn for the debt portfolio of JPMorgan''s principal investment group.

The sale underscores the extent to which shadow banks are taking over lucrative parts of the operations of big commercial banks, which are under pressure to raise capital and play down certain activities to meet new Basel requirements and regulatory constraints.

entry.author: By Camilla Hall in New York
entry.headline: Dimon reassures investors on cancer as JPMorgan beats estimates
entry.body: EPA

entry.author: By Josh Noble in Hong Kong
entry.headline: JPMorgan picks David Li to head probe-hit China division
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Caroline Binham, Legal Correspondent
entry.headline: Ex-JPMorgan trader challenges whale'' findings
entry.body:
A former JPMorgan Chase trader who faces US criminal charges in the wake of the $6bn London whale debacle is challenging civil findings made against the bank by the UK financial watchdog.

Julien Grout, a French national who worked as a junior credit-derivatives trader at the time of the $6bn loss that rocked the bank in 2012, has filed an appeal with a London tribunal taking issue with the UK Financial Conduct Authority''s findings against JPMorgan that were part of the bank''s $1bn settlement with US and UK authorities last year, according to tribunal records.

entry.author: By Jamil Anderlini in Beijing and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Former JPMorgan China banker questioned in HK
entry.body: AFP

entry.author: By Caroline Binham, Legal Correspondent
entry.headline: London coroner rules JPMorgan manager''s death was suicide
entry.body:
Reuters

William Magee, father of JPMorgan technology expert Gabriel Magee, speaks outside Poplar coroner''s court on Tuesday

entry.author: By Sam Fleming
entry.headline: Former Italian finance chief Vittorio Grilli to join JPMorgan
entry.body:
Bloomberg

Vittorio Grilli, former Italian finance minister

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York, John Paul Rathbone in London and Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan shuts foreign diplomats'' accounts
entry.body:
Bloomberg

Colombia''s former finance minister Jose Antonio Ocampo

entry.author: fer in London and Richard Milne in Oslo
entry.headline: Citi wins Norway fund business from JPMorgan
entry.body:
Citigroup has been chosen to safeguard the securities of the world''s biggest sovereign wealth fund after wooing away one of the largest custodian mandates from its rival JPMorgan.

The transfer of the Norwegian oil fund''s $865bn portfolio to its US competitor is a setback for JPMorgan, which is one of the top three competitors in the rapidly growing custodian business.

entry.author: By Henny Sender and Tom Braithwaite in New York and Jamil Anderlini in Beijing
entry.headline: JPMorgan''s head of China Zili Shao moved to fresh role
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase''s head of China is stepping down from the role after a controversial five years running a unit that is now mired in the princeling scandal roiling the largest US bank by assets.

Zili Shao''s move from head of China to vice-chairman of Asia Pacific was announced hastily by the bank on Friday after enquiries from the Financial Times.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan misses targets as revenues in fixed income slump
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase had its worst start to the year in fixed income trading since the depths of the financial crisis, causing the largest US bank to report a sharp decline in profits.

Revenues from trading bonds, currencies and commodities fell 21 per cent in the first quarter to $3.8bn, compared with the same period in 2013.

By the numbers: JPMorgan

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan''s Masters withdraws from line of fire

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Arash Massoudi in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan restructures unit that housed the London whale''
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has restructured its chief investment office, the former home of the London whale, in a further step away from the risky strategy that caused more than $6bn of losses, according to people familiar with the matter.

The bank said in an internal memo on Monday that it was combining its CIO and treasury in an organisation that mirrors the asset and liability management functions of a traditional bank.

entry.author: By Stephen Foley in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan deal builds new US pensions challenger to Fidelity
entry.body:
Bob Reynolds, the former number two at Fidelity, has signalled his ambition to challenge his former firm''s dominance of the US pension market with a deal to add JPMorgan Chase''s retirement services business to his growing empire at Great-West Financial.

The acquisition comes just weeks after Great-West merged its US pension administration business with that of its sister company, Putnam Investments, and put Mr Reynolds in charge of the combined group. He was hired to run Putnam, another subsidiary of Canada''s Great-West Lifeco, in 2008, a year after leaving Fidelity.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Blythe Masters quits JPMorgan after 27 years
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Kathrin Hille in Moscow and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Russian threat to retaliate over JPMorgan block
entry.body:
Russia has threatened to retaliate against US diplomatic missions after JPMorgan Chase blocked a money transfer from a Russian embassy, in the clearest political fallout so far from sanctions imposed over the annexation of Crimea last month.

The Russian foreign ministry said JPMorgan had blocked a transfer by Russia''s embassy in Astana, the capital of Kazakhstan, to Sogaz, an insurance company part-owned by Bank Rossiya, one of the targets of US sanctions announced on March 20.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite, Anne-Sylvaine Chassany and Henny Sender
entry.headline: JPMorgan executive Mike Cavanagh quits for Carlyle
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York and Jamil Anderlini in Beijing
entry.headline: Top JPMorgan China banker retires amid hiring probe
entry.body:
One of JPMorgan Chase''s top bankers in China is leaving the bank amid an investigation into its hiring practices in Asia.

Fang Fang, JPMorgan''s head of investment banking in China, is retiring after 12 years at the bank, according to an internal memo sent to the US bank''s staff on Monday.

entry.author: By Neil Hume in London and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan sells physical commodities unit to Mercuria for $3.5bn
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has agreed to sell its physical commodities business to Mercuria, the Geneva-based trading house, for $3.5bn, becoming the latest investment bank to scale back its activities in the sector.

The deal, which is expected to close in the third quarter of 2014, will lift privately owned Mercuria into upper tier of global commodity traders alongside Vitol, Trafigura, and Gunvor.

entry.author: By Ed Hammond and Arash Massoudi in New York
entry.headline: Blue Buffalo appoints JPMorgan for listing
entry.body:
Blue Buffalo, the luxury dog food brand, has hired JPMorgan to lead its initial public offering in a listing that is expected to value the business at more than $2bn.

The company, which has a sideline in cat food products, has also hired Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Barclays and Deutsche Bank for a listing that could come later this year, people familiar with its thinking said.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan targets $30bn war chest
entry.body: AFP

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan Chase to cut thousands more jobs
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase is planning more job cuts in its mortgage business on top of the 13,000-15,000 positions already due to be slashed because of plunging demand for home loans.

Several thousand more cuts are planned, according to people familiar with the matter, and could be announced at JPMorgan''s annual investor day on Tuesday. They are part of a new efficiency drive at the largest US bank by assets that also encompasses staffing branches with fewer employees.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan avoids third showdown over Dimon role
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has avoided a third successive showdown with shareholders at its annual meeting in Florida by convincing activists to forgo a vote on whether the bank should split the roles of chairman and chief executive.

Jamie Dimon holds both positions and last year''s meeting in Tampa saw a contentious vote over whether to strip him of one of the roles in the wake of the London whale trading fiasco. After lobbying from both sides, the bank ultimately quelled revolt over the issue.

entry.author: By Gina Chon in Washington and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: Legality of JPMorgan''s $13bn settlement with DoJ tested
entry.body:
The US justice department reached a secretive, backroom deal when it agreed to a landmark $13bn settlement with JPMorgan Chase to resolve allegations that the bank mis-sold mortgage securities, according to a lawsuit filed on Monday.

Better Markets, a non-profit group that promotes the public interest in financial markets, is asking a court to declare the settlement unlawful and issue an injunction to prevent the DoJ from enforcing it until it has been reviewed and approved by a judge.

entry.author: By Gregory Meyer and Camilla Hall in New York and Neil Hume in London
entry.headline: JPMorgan nears commodities sale
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase moved closer to a sale of its physical commodities business on Wednesday, when the bank entered exclusive talks with the trading house Mercuria, according to a person close to the situation.

If a deal is finalised, it will lift the Geneva-based company to the upper tier of global commodities traders while sharply curtailing JPMorgan''s presence in the oil, natural gas and coal markets.

entry.author: fer and Sam Fleming in London
entry.headline: JPMorgan raises alarm over rising euroscepticism in Britain
entry.body:
JPMorgan has warned that the UK could lose its clout in transatlantic trade and regulatory disputes if it exits the European Union, in the latest example of City alarm about rising euroscepticism in Britain.

The US bank said in a submission to the UK Treasury that London is more likely to get what it wants in negotiations over cross-border rules if it negotiates as part of the EU.

entry.author: By Lina Saigol
entry.headline: JPMorgan rainmaker Klaus Diederichs to retire
entry.body: Reuters

entry.author: By Paul J Davies in Hong Kong
entry.headline: JPMorgan bows out of IPO amid Asia hiring probe
entry.body:
JPMorgan has bowed out of a potentially lucrative role in the $1bn Hong Kong listing of a Chinese chemicals company due to the investigation into the US bank''s hiring of princelings.

The bank was one of several institutions working with Tianhe Chemicals towards a listing but decided to end its involvement when an internal risk review noted that the daughter of the company''s chairman had worked at JPMorgan, according to people familiar with the situation.

entry.author: By Jane Croft Law Courts Correspondent
entry.headline: German transport authority claims it was misled'' by JPMorgan
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase knew or ought to have known that a German transport authority was naive in the world of complex credit derivatives when the investment bank sold it a complex deal, it has been claimed in court documents.

The court papers relate to a trial in which the US bank is suing Berlin''s transport authority BVG for $204m over a collateralised debt obligation which the German authority took out in July 2007.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite
entry.headline: Muted JPMorgan quarter raises doubts over sector''s health
entry.body: Reuters

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Camilla Hall in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan profits dragged down by legal bills
entry.body:
AP

Jamie Dimon, chief executive

entry.author: By Jane Croft, Law Courts Correspondent
entry.headline: JPMorgan in $200m lawsuit against Berlin transport authority
entry.body:
JPMorgan and BVG, the Berlin transport authority, are set to begin a $200m High Court trial over a complex credit default swap arrangement signed before the 2008 financial crisis.

The case, which is due to last 10 weeks, will be closely watched as it is the first of a number of lawsuits to come to trial involving European public authorities that used complex financial instruments before the credit crunch.

entry.author: By Guy Chazan
entry.headline: Ex-JPMorgan dealmaker wins green light for Afghan mine
entry.body:
A mining company set up by Ian Hannam, the former JPMorgan dealmaker, has won approval from the Afghan government to develop a big copper deposit in the north-west of Afghanistan.

Afghan Gold and Minerals Company (AGMC) won the licence for the deposit, known as Balkhab, in 2012 but only agreed on terms for the contract to develop it with the Afghan Ministry of Mines last October.

entry.author: By Ed Hammond, US Mergers and Acquisitions Correspondent
entry.headline: Former JPMorgan dealmaker James Woolery to chair Cadwalader
entry.body:
Bloomberg

James Woolery

entry.author: By Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan hires ex-IMF director to lead Asian regulation strategy
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has hired Anoop Singh, the former director of the International Monetary Fund''s Asia-Pacific department, to be head of regulatory strategy in that region.

The newly created position, which will be announced on Thursday, comes amid a probe into JPMorgan''s hiring practices in China and a global investigation into the manipulation of foreign exchange trading that has ensnared other banks.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan sets record with $2.6bn Madoff payment
entry.body: EPA

entry.author: By Gregory Meyer and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Gripes over JPMorgan''s commodities sale
entry.body:
Bidders for JPMorgan Chase''s physical commodities business have complained that the bank is refusing to release enough information for them to value the assets.

The sale has presented a challenge for bankers running the process as they are negotiating with some of their fiercest trading rivals.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan shoots the instant messenger
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase''s investment banking co-heads banned their staff from using multi-bank instant messaging services on Wednesday, the latest sign of banks clamping down on a tool blemished by its use in market manipulation.

In a memo to staff, Mike Cavanagh and Daniel Pinto said that effective immediately all staff were prohibited from participating in electronic chats or instant messaging groups with two or more other banks/dealers.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York and Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan sues FDIC for more than $1bn
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase sued the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on Tuesday, striking back against the government weeks after agreeing to pay $13bn to resolve claims that it mis-sold mortgage securities.

The largest bank in the US said it was trying to recover substantially in excess of a billion dollars from the FDIC, which managed the receivership of Washington Mutual after the bank failed during the crisis and then sold most of its assets to JPMorgan.

entry.author: By Henny Sender and Tom Braithwaite
entry.headline: JPMorgan to sell Asia investment business
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has put up for sale its Global Special Opportunities Group, an Asia-based principal investment business, for a valuation likely to be more than $1bn.

The largest US bank has been talking to numerous private equity firms and credit-focused hedge funds about the transaction, as part of an effort to streamline its operations and anticipate regulatory trends, according to people familiar with the situation.

entry.author: By Chris Newlands
entry.headline: JPMorgan to shut 1bn money fund
entry.body:
AFP

JPMorgan is to merge its 949m Euro Government Liquidity fund into its 11.1bn Euro Liquidity product

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan to pay $2bn to settle Madoff claims
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has tentatively agreed to pay $2bn to settle allegations it failed to inform US authorities of suspicious activity from Bernard Madoff, according to people familiar with negotiations between the bank and the Department of Justice.

The Justice Department has accused the bank of failing to pass on concerns about Madoff, who had an account with the bank, and was arrested five years ago this week as his $20bn Ponzi scheme came to light.

entry.author: By Tracy Alloway in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan files patent for Bitcoin-style payment system

entry.author: By Gregory Meyer in New York and Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan eyed sale of metals unit in 2012
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase drew up plans to sell part of its metals warehousing empire last year as it faced pressure to show regulators that the business fitted with the activities of a bank, according to newly released documents.

A letter from the Federal Reserve obtained by the FT shows that the bank was working on the divestiture plan, some eight months before it publicly put up for sale its physical commodities business, which includes the Henry Bath warehousing unit.

entry.author: By Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan woes cause first fall in US bank income in four years
entry.body: Reuters

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan agrees $13bn settlement over mortgage securities
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase agreed on Tuesday to pay $13bn in a landmark settlement with the US Department of Justice and state authorities for mis-selling mortgage securities, but fought to contain the damage.

The size and scope of this resolution should send a clear signal that the justice department''s financial fraud investigations are far from over, said Eric Holder, US attorney-general. No firm, no matter how profitable, is above the law, and the passage of time is no shield from accountability.

You need JavaScript active on your browser in order to see this video.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan agrees to shoulder WaMu bill
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has conceded it will take responsibility for the past misdeeds of Washington Mutual, according to people familiar with the matter, paving the way for the Department of Justice to announce the biggest ever settlement with a single company.

People close to the sometimes fractious talks over the US government''s investigation into mortgage securities mis-selling say that the DoJ is poised to announce a $13bn settlement with JPMorgan on Tuesday after the bank accepted it would not try to claim back part of the costs from the government-managed receivership of WaMu.

You need JavaScript active on your browser in order to see this video.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan to pay $4.5bn over mis-selling mortgage securities

entry.author: By Camilla Hall in New York and Hannah Kuchler in San Francisco
entry.headline: JPMorgan feels the wrath of Twitter
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase cancelled a planned question and answer session on Twitter after the event attracted thousands of verbal attacks, in what may go down as a case study in how not to market on the social media website.

Jimmy Lee, one of the senior bankers that worked on Twitter''s share sale, was set to take over JPMorgan''s Twitter handle in an online marketing event on Thursday with the hashtag #AskJPM.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Shannon Bond in New York
entry.headline: New York police chief in talks on JPMorgan security role
entry.body:
Ray Kelly, the uncompromising chief of the New York Police Department, is in talks to join JPMorgan Chase in a senior security-related role, according to people familiar with the matter.

Winning plaudits for the falling New York City murder rate but attracting criticism for the force''s stop-and-frisk policy, Mr Kelly would be a controversial choice for JPMorgan. And the bank, which is mired in investigations into diverse business practices including by the Federal Bureau of Investigation would be a contentious employer for the police commissioner.

entry.author: By Madison Marriage
entry.headline: JPMorgan succumbs to fee pressure
entry.body:
Charlie Bibby

Nordic investors are demanding lower fees

entry.author: By Camilla Hall and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Citigroup and JPMorgan confirm forex investigations
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York and Gina Chon in Washington
entry.headline: JPMorgan to pay $5bn in FHFA deal
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase agreed to pay $5.1bn in a deal with a government housing regulator, resolving a large part of the allegations that it mis-sold mortgage-backed securities in the run-up to the financial crisis.

The announcement by the Federal Housing Finance Agency on Friday ends one part of protracted legal negotiations that are expected to see the largest US bank by assets pay $13bn to the US government.

entry.author: By Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan settlement move spurs rivals to act
entry.body:
Global banks have started to approach New York''s attorney-general about paying billions of dollars to settle charges they mis-sold mortgage-backed securities that were at the heart of the financial crisis, following JPMorgan Chase''s tentative agreement to a $13bn settlement.

I have already had expressions of interest from other institutions, Eric Schneiderman, New York attorney-general, said in an interview with the Financial Times.

entry.author: By Stephen Foley, Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan nears $6bn settlement with investors
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase is nearing a $6bn settlement with institutional investors to resolve claims it mis-sold mortgage-backed securities, according to people familiar with the matter.

The settlement discussions started almost two years ago but have accelerated recently. They are separate to a $13bn deal that the bank has cut with the Department of Justice to resolve US government claims that the bank sold MBS riddled with bad loans in the run-up to the financial crisis.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite, Kara Scannell and Camilla Hall
entry.headline: Opinion divided on JPMorgan settlement
entry.body:
The $13bn settlement JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay to US state and federal authorities has divided opinion in the US.

Much of Wall Street and many of its lawyers believe the government has pulled off a shakedown, using the implicit threat of criminal prosecution to rake in billions of dollars.

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite
entry.headline: JPMorgan reaches $13bn deal with US authorities
entry.body:
Bloomberg

JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon testifies before Senate Banking Committee

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan nears $4bn mortgage claims deal
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase is nearing an agreement to pay $4bn to settle allegations by the Federal Housing Finance Agency that it mis-sold mortgage-backed securities, according to people familiar with the matter.

The negotiations between the bank and the housing regulator are part of broader talks to resolve allegations of mortgage wrongdoing that also involve the US Department of Justice and Eric Schneiderman, the New York attorney-general.

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: CFTC split over JPMorgan whale'' deal
entry.body:
The Commodity Futures Trading Commission split over the $100m London whale settlement with JPMorgan Chase with one commissioner insisting that the agency should have tried to prove the bank intentionally manipulated a key index.

In settling with the futures regulator on Wednesday, JPMorgan signed an agreement admitting it was reckless when it employed a manipulative device in trading $7bn of credit default swaps in early 2012. The bank accepted the CFTC''s version of the facts, but did not admit that it violated the law.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan agrees to $100m CFTC fine over London whale''
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay $100m and accepted its London whale trading episode had a manipulative effect on credit derivatives markets in a settlement with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, according to people familiar with the situation.

The CFTC was noticeably absent from a $920m settlement between the largest US bank and four regulators in the US and UK last month. Until recently talks had floundered over the question of whether the bank would admit that it manipulated a credit default index known as the IG9 when trading derivatives at the heart of the whale debacle.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan''s legal burden sends shivers through the industry
entry.body: A substantial part of JPMorgan''s bill is associated with the activities of Bear Stearns and Washington Mutual companies the US government was delighted to see rescued in 2008

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan falls to first loss under Dimon
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase fell to its first loss under Jamie Dimon, after being engulfed in a legal and regulatory storm that cost the bank $9.2bn in litigation charges in the third quarter.

It''s very painful for me personally, said Mr Dimon as he announced the end of an unrivalled record of profit since becoming chief executive in 2005.

JPMorgan and Wells Fargo

entry.author: By Gregory Meyer in New York and Neil Hume in London
entry.headline: JPMorgan draws interest in commodities arm
entry.body:
More than two dozen parties, including pension funds and trading houses, have expressed interest in JPMorgan Chase''s physical commodities operations following the bank''s decision in July to divest the business.

First round offers for the business, one of Wall Street''s biggest traders of cargoes of oil, coal and natural gas, are due before the end of the month, according to people familiar with the situation.

entry.author: By Robert Jenkins
entry.headline: Has JPMorgan become an argument for breaking up the banks?

entry.author: By Ellen Kelleher
entry.headline: JPMorgan plans to axe 100 of 650 funds
entry.body:
JPMorgan Asset Management plans to axe 100 of the 650 funds in its stable of active funds and plough the money it saves into the creation of new products.

The move to cut as much as 15 per cent of its line-up across Asia and the US comes after JPMorgan opted to cull 49 of its funds in Europe by the first quarter of next year.

entry.author: By Rachel Sanderson in Milan
entry.headline: Italian prosecutors seek trial for JPMorgan
entry.body: Reuters

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: US judge holds key to JPMorgan settlement
entry.body: U.S. District Court, SDNY

entry.author: By Robert Budden, Chief Media Correspondent
entry.headline: Stephanie Flanders to quit BBC for JPMorgan
entry.body:
Stephanie Flanders, economics editor at the BBC, is leaving the public service broadcaster after 11 years to take up a senior role at JPMorgan Asset Management.

In November, she will become chief market strategist in the UK and Europe for the US investment bank''s fund management arm, bringing to an end a career in journalism that has spanned almost two decades.

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan eyes $4bn pay for peace'' deal
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Kara Scannell, Tom Braithwaite and Tracy Alloway in New York
entry.headline: Rebuke makes grim reading for JPMorgan Chase''s Jamie Dimon
entry.body:
Reuters

Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan''s chief executive

entry.author: fer in London
entry.headline: UK flexes regulatory muscle with JPMorgan fine
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase''s $920m settlement over its trading fiasco marks the first time that a London authority has been at eye''s level with its transatlantic counterparts in handing out painful fines, highlighting a much stricter penalty policy.

Until recently, UK regulators have lagged behind their US peers in terms of the financial pain they inflicted, often handing out fines that were a multiple of 10 smaller than their US counterparts. But the 137.6m levied by the UK''s new Financial Conduct Authority on Thursday ranks second among the four simultaneous penalties slapped on JPMorgan.

entry.author: fer and Lina Saigol
entry.headline: Regulators highlight JPMorgan deficiencies''
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase on Thursday agreed to a $920m fine from US and UK regulators over last year''s London whale credit derivative trading fiasco that caused more than $6bn in losses and severely dented the bank''s reputation for savvy risk management.

You need JavaScript active on your browser in order to see this video.

entry.author: fer in London
entry.headline: JPMorgan hit with $920m in fines over whale'' trade
entry.body:
US and UK authorities slammed JPMorgan Chase''s senior management for having deprived its board of critical information about the London whale trading fiasco and hit the bank with $920m in fines.

You need JavaScript active on your browser in order to see this video.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan braced for action over whale''
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase is expected to be accused of failing to provide accurate and timely information on the London whale trading fiasco to regulators, investors and its board, in a transatlantic enforcement action due to hit the bank on Thursday.

You need JavaScript active on your browser in order to see this video.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: Jamie Dimon memo outlines simplified JPMorgan structure
entry.body:
AP

Jamie Dimon, chief executive

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan in talks to pay $800m whale'' fine
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase is in talks to pay at least $800m to settle with securities and bank regulators over the $6bn London whale trading loss, but faces additional fines from US derivatives regulators not part of the current pact, people familiar with the matter said.

The largest bank in the US by assets is expected to admit wrongdoing in settlements with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Federal Reserve, Office of Comptroller of the Currency and the UK''s Financial Conduct Authority, these people added.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Stephen Foley in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan appoints Michael Neal and Linda Bammann to board
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase appointed two new board members and strengthened the role of its lead independent director but failed to satisfy some of the shareholders agitating for improved corporate governance.

Michael Neal, former chief executive of GE Capital, and Linda Bammann, former deputy chief risk officer of JPMorgan, will join the board in the next few months, the bank said on Monday.

entry.author: By Nick Reeve
entry.headline: Fund focus: USA all the way for JPMorgan
entry.body:
Fund of funds veteran Tony Lanning is looking to the US stock market to drive the performance of his new JPMorgan Fusion product range.

The five multi-manager funds, which avoid buying individual companies and instead focus on buying other funds, were launched in March to cater for a variety of risk appetites.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan hiring probe expands in Asia
entry.body:
An expanding investigation into JPMorgan Chase''s hiring practices in Asia has uncovered internal documents that link dozens of new employees with specific deals that the bank was trying to win, according to people familiar with the situation.

JPMorgan''s lawyers are turning over information to the US Securities and Exchange Commission and Department of Justice as part of a probe into whether the bank hired the family members of influential figures in the Chinese government and elsewhere in Asia in an effort to win business.

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan woes deepen as US demands $6bn penalty
entry.body: AFP

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite and Kara Scannell in New York
entry.headline: Regulator battlesthreatentoswampJPMorgan
entry.body:
In April, Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, previously the posterchild of resilience in the financial crisis and now the target of more lawsuits and investigations than any other bank, warned: We expect we will have more regulatory orders to deal with. His prediction has come true in many areas.

London Whale

entry.author: By Kara Scannell in New York and Tobias Buck in Madrid
entry.headline: Former JPMorgan banker Javier Martin-Artajo arrested in Spain
entry.body:
Spanish police on Tuesday arrested Javier Martin-Artajo, the former JPMorgan Chase banker accused of hiding hundreds of millions of dollars in losses from the London whale trade, Spain''s interior ministry said.

The arrest comes just 10 days after US authorities charged Mr Martin-Artajo and Julien Grout, a junior bank employee, with falsifying bank records by artificially inflating the value of derivative trades to avoid losses.

entry.author: By Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Len Blavatnik wins $50m in JPMorgan lawsuit
entry.body:
Bloomberg

Len Blavatnik, joint defendant with Viktor Vekselberg in action brought by Leonid Lebedev

entry.author: By Kara Scannell and Tracy Alloway in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan hires top law firm over Hong Kong probe
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase has hired a venerable New York law firm to conduct an internal investigation into its hiring practices in Hong Kong as the bank struggles to understand the potential depth of the issue.

Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison was retained by the bank, people familiar with the matter said, to respond to the Securities and Exchange Commission''s inquiry into the bank''s hiring of a son of a former Chinese banking regulator and daughter of a Chinese railway official.

entry.author: By Tracy Alloway in New York
entry.headline: JPMorgan pledges to clean up legal woes
entry.body:
When JPMorgan Chase emerged from the financial crisis as one of the stronger banks left in the US financial industry, the list of legal proceedings it published as part of its quarterly regulatory filings ran to two pages. Fast forward five years and that list has jumped to a startling 10 pages long.

The bank, now the second-biggest in the US by market capitalisation, has been inundated by a string of recent regulatory investigations, ranging from continued fallout over the $6bn London Whale trading loss it incurred last year to a new criminal probe related to the sale of mortgage-backed securities before the financial crisis.

entry.author: By Sam Fleming and Philip Stafford
entry.headline: JPMorgan tells clearers to build bigger buffers
entry.body:
Clearing houses which guarantee the smooth completion of financial transactions ranging from derivatives trades to commodities deals should be required to line up larger financial buffers to prevent triggering a future market disaster, a top investment bank has argued.

JPMorgan Chase is to warn in a forthcoming paper that the current system for dealing with failing clearing houses is brittle and opaque, and requires a new resolution framework to tackle major failures.

entry.author: By Martin Arnold, Banking Editor
entry.headline: Sir Win Bischoff to take chairman role at JPMorgan Securities
entry.body: Charlie Bibby

entry.author: By Henny Sender in New York
entry.headline: Sankaty to buy JPMorgan debt portfolio for $1bn
entry.body:
Sankaty Advisors, the credit arm of Bain Capital, is paying more than $1bn for the debt portfolio of JPMorgan''s principal investment group.

The sale underscores the extent to which shadow banks are taking over lucrative parts of the operations of big commercial banks, which are under pressure to raise capital and play down certain activities to meet new Basel requirements and regulatory constraints.

entry.author: By Camilla Hall in New York
entry.headline: Dimon reassures investors on cancer as JPMorgan beats estimates
entry.body: EPA

entry.author: By Josh Noble in Hong Kong
entry.headline: JPMorgan picks David Li to head probe-hit China division
entry.body: Bloomberg

entry.author: By Caroline Binham, Legal Correspondent
entry.headline: Ex-JPMorgan trader challenges whale'' findings
entry.body:
A former JPMorgan Chase trader who faces US criminal charges in the wake of the $6bn London whale debacle is challenging civil findings made against the bank by the UK financial watchdog.

Julien Grout, a French national who worked as a junior credit-derivatives trader at the time of the $6bn loss that rocked the bank in 2012, has filed an appeal with a London tribunal taking issue with the UK Financial Conduct Authority''s findings against JPMorgan that were part of the bank''s $1bn settlement with US and UK authorities last year, according to tribunal records.

entry.author: By Jamil Anderlini in Beijing and Tom Braithwaite in New York
entry.headline: Former JPMorgan China banker questioned in HK
entry.body: AFP

entry.author: By Caroline Binham, Legal Correspondent
entry.headline: London coroner rules JPMorgan manager''s death was suicide
entry.body:
Reuters

William Magee, father of JPMorgan technology expert Gabriel Magee, speaks outside Poplar coroner''s court on Tuesday

entry.headline: Former Italian finance chief Vittorio Grilli to join JPMorgan

Bloomberg

Vittorio Grilli, former Italian finance minister

entry.headline: JPMorgan shuts foreign diplomats'' accounts
entry.body:
Bloomberg

Colombia''s former finance minister Jose Antonio Ocampo

entry.author: fer in London and Richard Milne in Oslo
entry.headline: Citi wins Norway fund business from JPMorgan
entry.body:
Citigroup has been chosen to safeguard the securities of the world''s biggest sovereign wealth fund after wooing away one of the largest custodian mandates from its rival JPMorgan.

The transfer of the Norwegian oil fund''s $865bn portfolio to its US competitor is a setback for JPMorgan, which is one of the top three competitors in the rapidly growing custodian business.

entry.author: By Henny Sender and Tom Braithwaite in New York and Jamil Anderlini in Beijing
entry.headline: JPMorgan''s head of China Zili Shao moved to fresh role
entry.body:
JPMorgan Chase''s head of China is stepping down from the role after a controversial five years running a unit that is now mired in the princeling scandal roiling the largest US bank by assets.

Zili Shao''s move from head of China to vice-chairman of Asia Pacific was announced hastily by the bank on Friday after enquiries from the Financial Times.
